entry.string:
# it turns out that while this library is billed as a Processing library it's dependancies on Processing are pretty slight. Let's start it up without any mention of Processing from hypermedia.video import * opencv = OpenCV(None)
width, height = 500, 500 opencv.capture(width, height)

from java.nio import ByteBuffer from field.graphics.core import AdvancedTextures from field.graphics.core.AdvancedTextures import BaseFastRawTexture from AdvancedGraphics import *
# now here's where we initialize Field's graphics system
canvas = getFullscreenCanvas()
# and we make a GLSLang shader (the source code for this shader is available in the drop down box above) shader = makeShaderFromElement(_self)
# we connect the shader to the canvas canvas << shader
# and we make a texture map backed by an IntBuffer data = ByteBuffer.allocateDirect(width*height*4).asIntBuffer() texture = BaseFastRawTexture("", data, width, height, None) shader << texture

# here we make a mesh mesh = dynamicMesh()
# connect it to the shader shader << mesh
# we put a square in it with mesh: mesh ** Vector3(0,0,0) mesh ** Vector3(1,0,0) mesh ** Vector3(1,1,0) mesh ** Vector3(0,1,0) mesh ** [0,1,2, 0,2,3]
# and we provide somethings that the shader will use for texture coordinates aux = mesh.aux(5, 2) aux.put([0,0, width,0, width,height, 0,height])

def updateATexture(): # we read an image from the camera opencv.read()
# and we copy it into our texture map data.rewind() data.put(opencv.image().pixels) data.rewind()
# remembering to tell Field that it needs to send the texture to the graphics card again texture.dirty()
_r = updateATexture

label= """Or : OpenCV+Field+OpenGL: Run all the code in the first three boxes once in turn, then option-click the 'update' box to keep updating the texture map with new video""" width=300 opacity=0.5 #--------------------------------------------- from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear() text = PLine().moveTo(5,5)(offsetFromSource=Vector2(0,0)) text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label) text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity) _self.lines.add(text) _self.noFrame=1 _self.lines.add(PLine().rect(Rect(_self.frame.x, _self.frame.y, _self.frame.w, _self.frame.h))(derived=1, color=Color4(0,0,0,0.3)))

label= """1. : OpenCV+Processing+Field: Run Start, then run hello opencv or blobs (works well with the P3D renderer.""" width=200 opacity=0.5 #--------------------------------------------- from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear() text = PLine().moveTo(5,5)(offsetFromSource=Vector2(0,0)) text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label) text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity) _self.lines.add(text) _self.noFrame=1 _self.lines.add(PLine().rect(Rect(_self.frame.x, _self.frame.y, _self.frame.w, _self.frame.h))(derived=1, color=Color4(0,0,0,0.3)))

from java.nio import ByteBuffer from field.graphics.core import AdvancedTextures from field.graphics.core.AdvancedTextures import BaseFastRawTexture from AdvancedGraphics import *
# now here's where we initialize Field's graphics system
# note, the additional 'clearBackground=0' option canvas = getFullscreenCanvas(clearBackground=0)
# if we arn't going to clear the background, we need to clear the depth buffer canvas << ClearDepth()
# and we make a GLSLang shader (the source code for this shader is available in the drop down box above) shader = makeShaderFromElement(_self)
# this is how we send a variable to the shdaer (you'll see it appear as a 'uniform') shader.myOffset=Vector4(0,0,0,0)
# we can also set this variable on geometry and geometry gets drawn with it (see the update box)
# we connect the shader to the canvas canvas << shader
# and we make a texture map backed by an IntBuffer data = ByteBuffer.allocateDirect(width*height*4).asIntBuffer() texture = BaseFastRawTexture("", data, width, height, None) shader << texture

# here we make a mesh mesh = dynamicMesh()
# connect it to the shader shader << mesh
# we put a square in it with mesh: mesh ** Vector3(0,0,0) mesh ** Vector3(1,0,0) mesh ** Vector3(1,1,0) mesh ** Vector3(0,1,0) mesh ** [0,1,2, 0,2,3]
# and we provide somethings that the shader will use for texture coordinates aux = mesh.aux(5, 2) aux.put([0,0, width,0, width,height, 0,height])

def updateATexture(): # we read an image from the camera opencv.read()
# and we copy it into our texture map data.rewind() data.put(opencv.image().pixels) data.rewind()
# remembering to tell Field that it needs to send the texture to the graphics card again texture.dirty()
mesh.myOffset = Vector4(Math.random(),Math.random(),Math.random(),Math.random())
_r = updateATexture
